The Holy One, Blessed is He, informed Moshe that He would reward Pinchas well for the act of vengeance he performed for Hashem, and for the kindness he bestowed on Yisroel to atone for them so they would not all die in the plague. He commanded him to inform Yisroel that Pinchas would be a kohein forever. That is the explanation to the words, “Therefore, tell” — that Moshe should inform Yisroel. Scripture did not say there would be an eternal kehunah for Pinchas and his seed after him, as it did regarding Aharon. Rather, it says, “A covenant of eternal kehunah” and “My covenant of peace” — that Hashem would give him a covenant with peace attached.

17.0: With their guiles. Hashem commanded them to take vengeance from the Midianites, but not the Moabites. The Midrash explains this was because the Moabites acted out of fear since Yisroel was looting and taking booty from them, but the Midianites mixed into a dispute that did not involve them, as Rashi wrote later on (31:2). Moreover, it can be explained, according to the plain meaning, as follows: Hashem gave the lands of Amon and Moav as an inheritance to Lot’s descendants, due to the merit of their family head Lot who served Avraham and went into exile with him to the Land of Canaan. Therefore, Hashem prohibited Bnei Yisroel from doing anything bad to them in their land. However, since the Moabites and Ammonites sinned by not offering food and drink to Bnei Yisroel and driving them away, Hashem punished them by driving them away from His people and commanded (Devorim 23:4): “Neither an Ammonite nor a Moabite may enter”, measure for measure.

8.0: Eliav’s sons were Nemueil, Dasan and Aviram. Scripture mentions this to inform that all the inheritance of the Paluite family went to Nemueil alone, because Dasan and Aviram and all their possessions were swallowed by the ground. According to the view of the Sages (Baba Basra 118b), the verse comes to hint that they lost their portion in the Land even though they were among those who left Egypt and were worthy of an estate.

41.0: These are the descendants of Don by their families. The explanation of this verse is that Shucham had a number of sons and they founded families that were named after them. However, all of them ascribed Shucham as their family head, and they were called by his name as well. For example, one of them was called the Daniel family, the Shuchamite, and one was the Yechezkel family, the Shuchamite. Accordingly, the sons of Don were comprised of many families, but they were all considered one family in relation to Shucham, and therefore the verse makes the connection of their entire lineage to him. According to the view that the families were connected to the lineage of those who left Egypt, there were many families of the sons of Shucham who were named after their founders who were born in Egypt, but here the verse connects them only to Shucham, because he alone went out from Egypt.

45.0: The name of Asher’s daughter was Serach. Rashi wrote: “Because she remained alive, she was counted here.” However, Onkelos translated the verse: “The name of the daughter of Asher’s wife was Serach.” This means that Serach was eligible for an inheritance in Eretz Yisroel. Therefore, that is why the Torah mentions her here, as it mentioned the daughters of Tzelofchad; Serach was included in the command: “The land shall be apportioned among these.” If she was the daughter of Asher himself she would not inherit because he had sons. Perforce, then, she was the daughter of his wife, the daughter of another man with no sons whose inheritance would go to his daughter. According to this, the explanation of, “and their sister Serach” (Bereishis 46:17) is that she was the sister of Asher’s sons but not his daughter. Therefore, it says here as well: The name of Asher’s daughter was Serach and not “Asher’s daughter was Serach” — which informs that she was called “Asher’s daughter” [but she was not actually his daughter] and she was named Serach.

56.0: These are the numbered ones of the Levites. I do not know why Scripture counts the Levites, and what benefit accrued now from their count. We can answer that perhaps the Levite cities for dwelling and their open spaces for livestock were given to these persons, but not for those born afterwards. Alternatively, perhaps Hashem commanded this count to honor them. The legion of the King should not be lessor than the others, so no one will say Hashem did not care enough about them to count them as everyone else.

62.0: This is the census of Moshe and Elozor. The word “this” relates to the census of the Israelites; the census of the Levites was not included, for regarding them the verse could not say (v. 64): “Among this [census] there was no man who had been included in the census of Moshe and Aharon the kohein, who had counted Bnei Yisroel in the Wilderness of Sinai.” This is because the decree was not decreed on the tribe of Levi, as the Sages said (Baba Basra 121b), and the proof is from Elozor and Pinchas.

63.0: Among this [census] there was no man who had been included in the census of Moshe and Aharon the kohein. [This verse does not say, “with the exception of Kaleiv son of Yefuneh and Yehoshua son of Nun] because Yehoshua and Caleiv were not included in this census as they were over sixty years of age, and the count was only from twenty years old to sixty. These years are the main years of a man, as implied regarding valuations (Vayikro 27:3,7); during this period a man goes forth to the army, and not after the age of sixty, as the Sages said (Baba Basra 121b). In the next verse, however, it does say: “No one was left with the exception of Kaleiv, son of Yefuneh and Yehoshua, son of Nun,” because they were in the first census and did not die.

2.0: But he was not. Rashi wrote: “Since they were going to say that he died because of his sin, they needed to say: Not the sin of the complainers, nor with Korach’s assembly, who incited [the people] against the Holy One, Blessed is He — was he. Rather, he died by his sin alone, without provoking others to sin with him.” However, Rashi did not explain why they needed to say he died because of his own sin. They could have simply said, “Our father died in the Wilderness without leaving any sons.” According to the view of our Sages (Baba Basra 117b) they needed to say he was not part of Korach’s assembly, because Korach’s assembly lost their portion in the Land of Israel, as did the complainers. The daughters knew this because the Beis Din of Moshe spread this information among the people. Rabbi Avraham (Ibn Ezra) explained this way as well, and wrote that the daughters thought that the group that banded together against Hashem would not inherit in the Land. In my view, according to the plain meaning, they said this because they thought Moshe hated Korach’s assembly more than all the other sinners who died in the Wilderness, since they rebelled against him and denounced all his deeds. They thought that maybe Moshe would say about Korach’s assembly, due to his hatred of them: “May he have none who extends kindness, and may no one be gracious to his orphans” (Tehillim 109:12); “May the iniquity against his forefathers be remembered by Adonoy” (ibid. 14). Therefore, the daughters informed him that their father was not a part of that assembly, and hinted that he was not among those who died in the plague; rather, he died in the Wilderness upon his bed. The meaning of, but he died because of his own sin, was that he died because of his sin in the Wilderness and did not merit to enter the Land.

11.0: Go up this Mount "Eivarim."  The name of this mountain is "Mount Nevo," as it is explained in [the Torah portions] Ha'azinu and V'zot Haberachah, but it is called "Mount Eivarim"--"Mount of the Crossings"--because it is at the crossing of the [River] Jordan.  And, there is where they will cross into the Land of Canaan, as it said there (in Ha'azinu and V'zot Haberachah), "...which is on the banks of the Jordan...," and there they crossed the Jordan, as it is said, (Joshua 4:19) "...And the people went up from the Jordan and camped in Gilgal on the eastern border of Jericho...."  And, it was not a mitzvah that the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded him (Moses) to do now, because if so, he would have been required to go up there immediately.  But rather, the reason for "go up Mount Eivarim and see  the Land..." was because He (God) commanded him, "To these the Land is to be allotted..." (Numbers 26:53).  Let it be known that you will not apportion the Land with your own hand, but rather you will go up to the top of Mount Eivarim before the people Israel travels from the land of Moab, and you will die upon it and nothing of the Land will reach you but the sight [of it].  And similarly, "Take Joshua..." (Numbers 27:18):  When your day comes, you will take Joshua and fulfill that which is written [in Numbers 27:22] that tells that Moses did so with a full heart - and this is the action that will be recalled (Deuteronomy 31:7) at the time of Moses' death, when the poem was said, "he and Hoshea son of Nun."

1.0: S.v. Moshe spoke to the tribal leaders: This section comes here since [the Torah recently] mentioned vows to the Higher Realm: "in addition to your vows and freewill offerings, be they burnt offerings, meal offerings, libations, or offerings of well-being" (Numbers 29:39). [Hence] it also stated, "Besides all of these vows and freewill offering, there are also the vows of the commoner. And a person is obligated to do everything that comes out of of his mouth, and to do everything that he has prohibited to himself. And in all of them, he 'shall not desecrate his word.' But others may allow it to him."

13.0: Every vow and every oath of self-denial. Rashi wrote: “Since it was said that the husband may annul, perhaps all vows are included; the Torah therefore teaches, ‘of self-denial.’ He may only annul vows which are of self-denial. They are defined in tractate Nedarim.” Rashi spoke briefly, for indeed the husband annuls vows which are of self-denial, for example, if she said, “the fruits of the world are prohibited to me.” Included in this is even if she vowed not to taste one type of fruit. However, besides these vows, the husband can annul matters between him and her even if they do not involve self-denial. For example, if she said I will not use eye mascara, or remove hair, or engage in marital relations. About these things it says (v. 17): “regarding a man and his wife,” as stated in Nedarim (79b).

15.0: He must bear her transgression. Rashi wrote: “He must take her place. We learn from here that one who causes another’s downfall must bear full punishment in his place.” The source of this is the Sifrei. It appears that this refers to a woman who violated her vow unintentionally or mistakenly. That is, the Torah speaks about a husband who heard about her vow and the woman did not know he heard. On a later day, he nullified it and told her that this was the day he heard about it. The Torah teaches two things here: 1) The husband bears the transgression as if he himself made a vow and transgressed it. 2) She is exempt and is not punished even for an unintentional sin. If, however, the woman knew that her husband did not annul on the day he heard about the vow, and she knows the law in this case, she is liable, and her husband did not cause her downfall. He will be punished only as one who could have protested and did not protest. The Torah mentions this in conjunction with a husband, but the same applies to a father. However, the Torah speaks about the usual case, for a father will usually not cause a downfall because he loves his daughter, but a husband might hate his wife and want to try to cause her to be guilty.

1.0: Take revenge for Bnei Yisroel. It was decreed that Moshe would not pass over the Yardein, but on the eastern side of the Yardein all the leadership roles were incumbent on him. He conquered the two great Emorite kings and apportioned their land for an inheritance. Thus, he was selected to take vengeance from the enemies of Hashem. Yehoshua, in contrast, had only the leadership roles that related to Eretz Yisroel. There was another reason Hashem gave Moshe the responsibility for this war. It was to honor him by allowing him to see the revenge enacted, as it says, “The righteous man will rejoice because he saw revenge” (Tehillim 58:11). These two reasons are the explanation of: Afterward you shall be gathered to your people. Moshe honored Pinchas, who had begun the mitzvah [when he killed Kosbi] and had the responsibility to finish the mitzvah. Moshe appointed Pinchas as the kohein meshuach milchamah—anointed for war. It was not appropriate to appoint Elozor, because he was the Kohein Gadol.

27.0: Levy a tribute to Adonoy. This tribute was given because the booty was from taking revenge for Hashem in a land that would not belong to Bnei Yisroel. In contrast, nothing was given to the kohanim and Levites in the war of Sichon and Og. Furthermore, the booty was prohibited to Bnei Yisroel, as it says (18:20): “And you will not have a share among them,” and on this the Sages explained: Even in the booty.

48.0: Your servants have taken a census. They were saying: Behold, Hashem made a great salvation through us [this is the interpretation of בידינו]. Of the soldiers who went out to war not one of us is missing, i.e., no one died during the war and no one was wounded by sword. Therefore, we want to bring an offering for Adonoy because He saved us, and to atone for ourselves because He redeemed us from death and from the sword. Our Sages interpreted (Shabbos 64a): Not one was of us was involved in a transgression. According to this interpretation, what the soldiers said was as follows: The soldiers who went to war were at all times “in our hands,” none of our brothers in the army were ever in another place where they could commit a transgression. Moshe asked them: So then why do you wish to bring an offering? They answered: To atone for ourselves because of illicit thoughts.

53.0: And they brought it … as a remembrance for Bnei Yisroel. From this language it seems that they made כלי שרת (ministering utensils) from the gold of these articles and gave them to the congregation, to the entire Bnei Yisroel, so they would perform the Divine service with these utensils for generations. If they had brought these articles to the treasury of Hashem’s house, then Scripture should have said, “As a remembrance for them before Adonoy.” The connotation of Bnei Yisroel is the entire nation, and remembrance connotes a lasting matter.

1.0: The Reubenites came first in v. 1, as they should have—Reuben was Jacob’s first-born  and also the son of his chief wife

18.0: Our inheritance came to us. Rashi wrote: We have already received it, on the eastern bank. [However, this is difficult because] it was not proper for them to say to Moshe that they have already received it. This was not something dependent on them. Rather, it depended on Moshe’s will, and they would not receive it until Moshe gave it to them. Instead, this is what they meant: But we do not want to take possession with them — this excludes their inheritance in the good land, for, our inheritance came to us — the inheritance that is appropriate for us, which is land for livestock, and we have more livestock than the other tribes. Thus, they were speaking as a request and not antagonistically (as in Rashi’s explanation). Alternatively, the explanation of, but we do not want to take possession with them, is: Even if you do not want to give us this land now, and we and all our possessions will cross over with the rest of the tribes, we will not take possession with them. Rather, we will return to this land, which is the appropriate inheritance for us, and what we want. None of the other tribes want it at all.

28.0: If the tribe of Gad and Reuvein will cross … you shall give them. At this point, Moshe did not hand over to them the entire land of Sichon and Og, he only gave them some cities in the land of Gil’ad, where there was pasture for their livestock. These were the cities of Ataros and Divon mentioned here (v. 34-35), which were built as fortified cities for their children and livestock. The rest of the land remained desolate, and therefore he commanded Yehoshua and the leaders: If the tribe of Gad and Reuvein will cross … you shall give them as a permanent possession. But if they will not agree to cross over with you, take all this land away from them, and drive their wives and children out of it. Give them the hereditary portion they deserve in the land of Canaan, which they will have to conquer when they are moved there.

30.0: The tribes of Gad and Reuvein answered. They were saying as follows: You, our master, do not need to command us with a double-sided condition, because we would never, God forbid, transgress what you, our master, has commanded. Your command is the word of Hashem and we would never transgress it. This is the meaning of: As Adonoy has spoken to your servants, as opposed to the previous promise they made (v. 25): “Your servants will do as my master instructs”.

32.0: Moshe gave to them. The Torah does not mention that Moshe divided the land of Sichon and Og between the tribes of Gad and Reuvein and that he gave a separate portion to each one of them. It only mentions in a general way that he gave them, and to half the tribe of Menashe, the empire of these two kings. However, in Devorim (3:13), he explained that he gave a separate portion to half the tribe of Menashe: “The entire Argov province throughout the Boshon.” That being so, we must explain that the Torah was brief and did not want to mention the division of these two tribes, since the division of the rest of the tribes was not mentioned. The Book of Yehoshua, however, states explicitly that Moshe gave a separate portion to each one of these two tribes, as we find regarding the tribe of Reuvein (Yehoshua 13:15): “And Moses gave to the tribe of the children of Reuvein inheritance according to their families”.

0.0: These are the journeys. Rambam in Moreh Nevuchim explained the benefit of knowing about the journeys in the Wilderness: There is a great need to mention the journeys, for the miracles and signs that happened in those places were true only for those who witnessed them, but in the future those miracles would only be things heard about, and it is possible for someone who only hears about things to deny them. The Torah speaks of awesome and wondrous miracles: Yisroel was in the Wilderness forty years and found manna every day. They journeyed in places far from civilization, places where there was no natural way for them to live, for it was “not a place of seed, figs, grapes, or pomegranates” (20:5). The Torah relates (Devorim 29:5): “Bread have you not eaten, neither fresh nor aged wine have you drunk.” All these things were open miracles that were seen to the eye. Since the Creator knew that these miracles would be affected by the same process [of forgetfulness and denial] that affects all historical events. He was concerned that the people who heard about them would not believe them. They would think that the places where Yisroel stayed were close to civilization and people could exist normally in them, like the desert places where the Arabs live today. Or perhaps they were places where they could plow and harvest, or there were herbs and plants for human consumption, and there were wells for water. Therefore, Hashem distanced such thoughts from people’s hearts. He strengthened the belief in these miracles by mentioning the journeys, so that the following generations would see the places and realize the great miracles that sustained Yisroel in those places forty years. These are the words of Rambam.

13.0: They camped in Refidim, [but] there was no water there for the people to drink. The miracle of the water in Moroh was not mentioned, nor was the miracle of the manna in the wilderness of Sin. However, what happened in Refidim was very important, for there they tested Hashem, and the place was named Massah and Merivah due to this. Moreover, Hashem was sanctified in their eyes when He extracted water from the rock, and there the war with Amalek was imposed upon them. Therefore, it was mentioned briefly that there was no water there for the people to drink because the place became well known through this.

52.0: And you shall take possession of the land and settle in it, for I have assigned the land for you to possess: In my opinion, this is a positive commandment. He commands them to settle in the land and inherit it; He gave it to them and they should not abhor Hashem's inheritance. And if it should enter their minds to go and conquer the land of Shinar or the land of Ashur [Assyria] or to settle in some other place, they would be transgressing Hashem's commandment. And our rabbis have stressed (Ketubot 110b) the commandment to settle in the Land of Israel and forbade leaving it; they judged a woman rebellious for not wanting to ascend with her husband to the Land of Israel, and vice-versa for a man. It is from here that this commandment [of settling in the land of Israel] has been commanded to us, as this verse is a positive commandment. It is a commandment that recurs in many places [in the Torah]; e.g., "go in and possess the land" (Deuteronomy 1:8). Rashi, however, interprets "And you shall take possession of the land" to mean that you shall take possession of it from those who have settled it, and then you will settle in it and be able to survive in it; and if you don't, you wouldn't be able to survive in it (Rashi on Numbers 33:53). But what we interpret is the central point of the verse.

28.0: In all your dwelling places. This teaches that the Sanhedrin can also convene outside Eretz Yisroel so long as it functions in Eretz Yisroel — Rashi. For the same reason, after the Destruction, it does not convene, neither inside nor outside Eretz Yisroel. As our Sages said (Sanhedrin 52b): It is written (Devorim 17:9): “You are to come before the Koheinim-the Levites and the judge officiating during those days.” During a period that there is a kohein, there is judgment, during a period where there is no kohein, there is not judgment. The Mechilta writes: How do we know that we cannot execute except when the Temple is standing: It is written (Shemos 21:14): “You may [even] take him from My altar to put him to death.” If there is an Altar, you can put him to death, if not, do not put to death. However, I did not find that it is said about any of the mitzvos that depend on the Temple: For all your descendants in all your dwelling places, because these words apply even during the time of exile and outside Eretz Yisroel. Similarly, these words imply that resting on the holiday of Shavuos and the prohibition of chadash (new wheat) are an obligation even today outside Eretz Yisroel. We should not err to make them conditional on the bringing of the Omer and the Mincha Chadashah. The same applies to cheilev (forbidden fat); we should not say that the prohibition is conditional on the sacrifices. Maybe the Sages expounded on the words (v. 29): These [rules] shall be for you the law of justice — that it refers to the Sanhedrin that was mentioned a number of times in the section, as it says (v. 12): “In judgment before the congregation” and (v. 24), “Then the congregation shall judge.” The verse here comes to say that we will have for all generations a judging congregation (Beis Din), even after the Destruction, to judge the laws of fines and theft and damages and all monetary matters and for the punishment of forty lashes.

32.0: Do not pollute the land. Since Scripture mentioned earlier (v. 29): “These [rules] shall be for you the law of justice for all your descendants in all your dwelling places,” to teach that these laws will apply even outside of Eretz Yisroel, it returns to be strict about the inhabitants of Eretz Yisroel even more, because of the honor of the Divine Presence. Thus, they must be careful not to pollute the Land.
